7. Geometric Series for Elementary Economics

7.1Overview¶

The lecture describes important ideas in economics that use the mathematics of geometric series.

Among these are

  • the Keynesian multiplier

  • the money multiplier that prevails in fractional reserve banking systems

  • interest rates and present values of streams of payouts from assets

(As we shall see below, the term multiplier comes down to meaning sum of a convergent geometric series)

These and other applications prove the truth of the wise crack that

Below we’ll use the following imports:

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (11, 5)  #set default figure size
import numpy as np
import sympy as sym
from sympy import init_printing
from matplotlib import cm

7.2Key formulas¶

To start, let ccc be a real number that lies strictly between -1 and 1.

  • We often write this as c∈(−1,1)c \in (-1,1)c∈(−1,1).

  • Here (−1,1)(-1,1)(−1,1) denotes the collection of all real numbers that are strictly less than 1 and strictly greater than -1.

  • The symbol ∈\in∈ means in or belongs to the set after the symbol.

We want to evaluate geometric series of two types -- infinite and finite.

7.2.1Infinite geometric series¶

The first type of geometric that interests us is the infinite series

1+c+c2+c3+⋯1 + c + c^2 + c^3 + \cdots1+c+c2+c3+⋯
(1)

Where ⋯\cdots⋯ means that the series continues without end.

The key formula is

1+c+c2+c3+⋯=11−c1 + c + c^2 + c^3 + \cdots = \frac{1}{1 -c }1+c+c2+c3+⋯=1−c1​
(2)

To prove key formula (2), multiply both sides by (1−c)(1-c)(1−c) and verify that if c∈(−1,1)c \in (-1,1)c∈(−1,1), then the outcome is the equation 1=11 = 11=1.

7.2.2Finite geometric series¶

The second series that interests us is the finite geometric series

1+c+c2+c3+⋯+cT1 + c + c^2 + c^3 + \cdots + c^T1+c+c2+c3+⋯+cT
(3)

where TTT is a positive integer.

The key formula here is

1+c+c2+c3+⋯+cT=1−cT+11−c1 + c + c^2 + c^3 + \cdots + c^T = \frac{1 - c^{T+1}}{1-c}1+c+c2+c3+⋯+cT=1−c1−cT+1​
(4)
Remark 1

The above formula works for any value of the scalar ccc. We don’t have to restrict ccc to be in the set (−1,1)(-1,1)(−1,1).

We now move on to describe some famous economic applications of geometric series.

7.3Example: The Money Multiplier in Fractional Reserve Banking¶

In a fractional reserve banking system, banks hold only a fraction r∈(0,1)r \in (0,1)r∈(0,1) of cash behind each deposit receipt that they issue

  • In recent times

    • cash consists of pieces of paper issued by the government and called dollars or pounds or …\ldots…

    • a deposit is a balance in a checking or savings account that entitles the owner to ask the bank for immediate payment in cash

  • When the UK and France and the US were on either a gold or silver standard (before 1914, for example)

    • cash was a gold or silver coin

    • a deposit receipt was a bank note that the bank promised to convert into gold or silver on demand; (sometimes it was also a checking or savings account balance)

Economists and financiers often define the supply of money as an economy-wide sum of cash plus deposits.

In a fractional reserve banking system (one in which the reserve ratio rrr satisfies 0<r<10 < r < 10<r<1), banks create money by issuing deposits backed by fractional reserves plus loans that they make to their customers.

A geometric series is a key tool for understanding how banks create money (i.e., deposits) in a fractional reserve system.

The geometric series formula (2) is at the heart of the classic model of the money creation process -- one that leads us to the celebrated money multiplier.

7.3.1A simple model¶

There is a set of banks named i=0,1,2,…i = 0, 1, 2, \ldotsi=0,1,2,….

Bank iii’s loans LiL_iLi​, deposits DiD_iDi​, and reserves RiR_iRi​ must satisfy the balance sheet equation (because balance sheets balance):

Li+Ri=DiL_i + R_i = D_iLi​+Ri​=Di​
(5)

The left side of the above equation is the sum of the bank’s assets, namely, the loans LiL_iLi​ it has outstanding plus its reserves of cash RiR_iRi​.

The right side records bank iii’s liabilities, namely, the deposits DiD_iDi​ held by its depositors; these are IOU’s from the bank to its depositors in the form of either checking accounts or savings accounts (or before 1914, bank notes issued by a bank stating promises to redeem notes for gold or silver on demand).

Each bank iii sets its reserves to satisfy the equation

Ri=rDiR_i = r D_iRi​=rDi​
(6)

where r∈(0,1)r \in (0,1)r∈(0,1) is its reserve-deposit ratio or reserve ratio for short

  • the reserve ratio is either set by a government or chosen by banks for precautionary reasons

Next we add a theory stating that bank i+1i+1i+1’s deposits depend entirely on loans made by bank iii, namely

Di+1=LiD_{i+1} = L_iDi+1​=Li​
(7)

Thus, we can think of the banks as being arranged along a line with loans from bank iii being immediately deposited in i+1i+1i+1

  • in this way, the debtors to bank iii become creditors of bank i+1i+1i+1

Finally, we add an initial condition about an exogenous level of bank 0’s deposits

D0  is given exogenouslyD_0 \ \text{ is given exogenously}D0​  is given exogenously
(8)

We can think of D0D_0D0​ as being the amount of cash that a first depositor put into the first bank in the system, bank number i=0i=0i=0.

Now we do a little algebra.

Combining equations (5) and (6) tells us that

Li=(1−r)DiL_i = (1-r) D_iLi​=(1−r)Di​
(9)

This states that bank iii loans a fraction (1−r)(1-r)(1−r) of its deposits and keeps a fraction rrr as cash reserves.

Combining equation (9) with equation (7) tells us that

Di+1=(1−r)Di  for i≥0D_{i+1} = (1-r) D_i \ \text{ for } i \geq 0Di+1​=(1−r)Di​  for i≥0
(10)

which implies that

Di=(1−r)iD0  for i≥0D_i = (1 - r)^i D_0 \ \text{ for } i \geq 0Di​=(1−r)iD0​  for i≥0
(11)

Equation (11) expresses DiD_iDi​ as the iii th term in the product of D0D_0D0​ and the geometric series

1,(1−r),(1−r)2,⋯1, (1-r), (1-r)^2, \cdots1,(1−r),(1−r)2,⋯
(12)

Therefore, the sum of all deposits in our banking system i=0,1,2,…i=0, 1, 2, \ldotsi=0,1,2,… is

∑i=0∞(1−r)iD0=D01−(1−r)=D0r\sum_{i=0}^\infty (1-r)^i D_0 = \frac{D_0}{1 - (1-r)} = \frac{D_0}{r}i=0∑∞​(1−r)iD0​=1−(1−r)D0​​=rD0​​
(13)

7.3.2Money multiplier¶

The money multiplier is a number that tells the multiplicative factor by which an exogenous injection of cash into bank 0 leads to an increase in the total deposits in the banking system.

Equation (13) asserts that the money multiplier is 1r\frac{1}{r}r1​

  • An initial deposit of cash of D0D_0D0​ in bank 0 leads the banking system to create total deposits of D0r\frac{D_0}{r}rD0​​.

  • The initial deposit D0D_0D0​ is held as reserves, distributed throughout the banking system according to D0=∑i=0∞RiD_0 = \sum_{i=0}^\infty R_iD0​=∑i=0∞​Ri​.

7.4Example: The Keynesian Multiplier¶

The famous economist John Maynard Keynes and his followers created a simple model intended to determine national income yyy in circumstances in which

  • there are substantial unemployed resources, in particular excess supply of labor and capital

  • prices and interest rates fail to adjust to make aggregate supply equal demand (e.g., prices and interest rates are frozen)

  • national income is entirely determined by aggregate demand

7.4.1Static version¶

An elementary Keynesian model of national income determination consists of three equations that describe aggregate demand for yyy and its components.

The first equation is a national income identity asserting that consumption ccc plus investment iii equals national income yyy:

c+i=yc+ i = yc+i=y
(14)

The second equation is a Keynesian consumption function asserting that people consume a fraction b∈(0,1)b \in (0,1)b∈(0,1) of their income:

c=byc = b yc=by
(15)

The fraction b∈(0,1)b \in (0,1)b∈(0,1) is called the marginal propensity to consume.

The fraction 1−b∈(0,1)1-b \in (0,1)1−b∈(0,1) is called the marginal propensity to save.

The third equation simply states that investment is exogenous at level iii.

  • exogenous means determined outside this model.

Substituting the second equation into the first gives (1−b)y=i(1-b) y = i(1−b)y=i.

Solving this equation for yyy gives

y=11−biy = \frac{1}{1-b} iy=1−b1​i
(16)

The quantity 11−b\frac{1}{1-b}1−b1​ is called the investment multiplier or simply the multiplier.

Applying the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric series, we can write the above equation as

y=i∑t=0∞bty = i \sum_{t=0}^\infty b^ty=it=0∑∞​bt
(17)

where ttt is a nonnegative integer.

So we arrive at the following equivalent expressions for the multiplier:

11−b=∑t=0∞bt\frac{1}{1-b} = \sum_{t=0}^\infty b^t1−b1​=t=0∑∞​bt
(18)

The expression ∑t=0∞bt\sum_{t=0}^\infty b^t∑t=0∞​bt motivates an interpretation of the multiplier as the outcome of a dynamic process that we describe next.

7.4.2Dynamic version¶

We arrive at a dynamic version by interpreting the nonnegative integer ttt as indexing time and changing our specification of the consumption function to take time into account

  • we add a one-period lag in how income affects consumption

We let ctc_tct​ be consumption at time ttt and iti_tit​ be investment at time ttt.

We modify our consumption function to assume the form

ct=byt−1c_t = b y_{t-1}ct​=byt−1​
(19)

so that bbb is the marginal propensity to consume (now) out of last period’s income.

We begin with an initial condition stating that

y−1=0y_{-1} = 0y−1​=0
(20)

We also assume that

it=i  for all t≥0i_t = i \ \ \textrm {for all } t \geq 0it​=i  for all t≥0
(21)

so that investment is constant over time.

It follows that

y0=i+c0=i+by−1=iy_0 = i + c_0 = i + b y_{-1} = iy0​=i+c0​=i+by−1​=i
(22)

and

y1=c1+i=by0+i=(1+b)iy_1 = c_1 + i = b y_0 + i = (1 + b) iy1​=c1​+i=by0​+i=(1+b)i
(23)

and

y2=c2+i=by1+i=(1+b+b2)iy_2 = c_2 + i = b y_1 + i = (1 + b + b^2) iy2​=c2​+i=by1​+i=(1+b+b2)i
(24)

and more generally

yt=byt−1+i=(1+b+b2+⋯+bt)iy_t = b y_{t-1} + i = (1+ b + b^2 + \cdots + b^t) iyt​=byt−1​+i=(1+b+b2+⋯+bt)i
(25)

or

yt=1−bt+11−biy_t = \frac{1-b^{t+1}}{1 -b } iyt​=1−b1−bt+1​i
(26)

Evidently, as t→+∞t \rightarrow + \inftyt→+∞,

yt→11−biy_t \rightarrow \frac{1}{1-b} iyt​→1−b1​i
(27)

Remark 1: The above formula is often applied to assert that an exogenous increase in investment of Δi\Delta iΔi at time 0 ignites a dynamic process of increases in national income by successive amounts

Δi,(1+b)Δi,(1+b+b2)Δi,⋯\Delta i, (1 + b )\Delta i, (1+b + b^2) \Delta i , \cdotsΔi,(1+b)Δi,(1+b+b2)Δi,⋯
(28)

at times 0,1,2,…0, 1, 2, \ldots0,1,2,….

Remark 2 Let gtg_tgt​ be an exogenous sequence of government expenditures.

If we generalize the model so that the national income identity becomes

ct+it+gt=ytc_t + i_t + g_t = y_tct​+it​+gt​=yt​
(29)

then a version of the preceding argument shows that the government expenditures multiplier is also 11−b\frac{1}{1-b}1−b1​, so that a permanent increase in government expenditures ultimately leads to an increase in national income equal to the multiplier times the increase in government expenditures.

7.5Example: Interest Rates and Present Values¶

We can apply our formula for geometric series to study how interest rates affect values of streams of dollar payments that extend over time.

We work in discrete time and assume that t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,… indexes time.

We let r∈(0,1)r \in (0,1)r∈(0,1) be a one-period net nominal interest rate

  • if the nominal interest rate is 5 percent, then r=.05r= .05r=.05

A one-period gross nominal interest rate RRR is defined as

R=1+r∈(1,2)R = 1 + r \in (1, 2)R=1+r∈(1,2)
(30)

  • if r=.05r=.05r=.05, then R=1.05R = 1.05R=1.05

Remark: The gross nominal interest rate RRR is an exchange rate or relative price of dollars at between times ttt and t+1t+1t+1. The units of RRR are dollars at time t+1t+1t+1 per dollar at time ttt.

When people borrow and lend, they trade dollars now for dollars later or dollars later for dollars now.

The price at which these exchanges occur is the gross nominal interest rate.

  • If I sell xxx dollars to you today, you pay me RxR xRx dollars tomorrow.

  • This means that you borrowed xxx dollars for me at a gross interest rate RRR and a net interest rate rrr.

We assume that the net nominal interest rate rrr is fixed over time, so that RRR is the gross nominal interest rate at times t=0,1,2,…t=0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,….

Two important geometric sequences are

1,R,R2,⋯1, R, R^2, \cdots1,R,R2,⋯
(31)

and

1,R−1,R−2,⋯1, R^{-1}, R^{-2}, \cdots1,R−1,R−2,⋯
(32)

Sequence (31) tells us how dollar values of an investment accumulate through time.

Sequence (32) tells us how to discount future dollars to get their values in terms of today’s dollars.

7.5.1Accumulation¶

Geometric sequence (31) tells us how one dollar invested and re-invested in a project with gross one period nominal rate of return accumulates

  • here we assume that net interest payments are reinvested in the project

  • thus, 1 dollar invested at time 0 pays interest rrr dollars after one period, so we have r+1=Rr+1 = Rr+1=R dollars at time1

  • at time 1 we reinvest 1+r=R1+r =R1+r=R dollars and receive interest of rRr RrR dollars at time 2 plus the principal RRR dollars, so we receive rR+R=(1+r)R=R2r R + R = (1+r)R = R^2rR+R=(1+r)R=R2 dollars at the end of period 2

  • and so on

Evidently, if we invest xxx dollars at time 0 and reinvest the proceeds, then the sequence

x,xR,xR2,⋯x , xR , x R^2, \cdotsx,xR,xR2,⋯
(33)

tells how our account accumulates at dates t=0,1,2,…t=0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,….

7.5.2Discounting¶

Geometric sequence (32) tells us how much future dollars are worth in terms of today’s dollars.

Remember that the units of RRR are dollars at t+1t+1t+1 per dollar at ttt.

It follows that

  • the units of R−1R^{-1}R−1 are dollars at ttt per dollar at t+1t+1t+1

  • the units of R−2R^{-2}R−2 are dollars at ttt per dollar at t+2t+2t+2

  • and so on; the units of R−jR^{-j}R−j are dollars at ttt per dollar at t+jt+jt+j

So if someone has a claim on xxx dollars at time t+jt+jt+j, it is worth xR−jx R^{-j}xR−j dollars at time ttt (e.g., today).

7.5.3Application to asset pricing¶

A lease requires a payments stream of xtx_txt​ dollars at times t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \ldotst=0,1,2,… where

xt=Gtx0x_t = G^t x_0xt​=Gtx0​
(34)

where G=(1+g)G = (1+g)G=(1+g) and g∈(0,1)g \in (0,1)g∈(0,1).

Thus, lease payments increase at ggg percent per period.

For a reason soon to be revealed, we assume that G<RG < RG<R.

The present value of the lease is

p0=x0+x1/R+x2/(R2)+⋯=x0(1+GR−1+G2R−2+⋯ )=x011−GR−1\begin{aligned} p_0 & = x_0 + x_1/R + x_2/(R^2) + \cdots \\ & = x_0 (1 + G R^{-1} + G^2 R^{-2} + \cdots ) \\ & = x_0 \frac{1}{1 - G R^{-1}} \end{aligned}p0​​=x0​+x1​/R+x2​/(R2)+⋯=x0​(1+GR−1+G2R−2+⋯)=x0​1−GR−11​​
(35)

where the last line uses the formula for an infinite geometric series.

Recall that R=1+rR = 1+rR=1+r and G=1+gG = 1+gG=1+g and that R>GR > GR>G and r>gr > gr>g and that rrr and ggg are typically small numbers, e.g., .05 or .03.

Use the Taylor series of 11+r\frac{1}{1+r}1+r1​ about r=0r=0r=0, namely,

11+r=1−r+r2−r3+⋯\frac{1}{1+r} = 1 - r + r^2 - r^3 + \cdots1+r1​=1−r+r2−r3+⋯
(36)

and the fact that rrr is small to approximate 11+r≈1−r\frac{1}{1+r} \approx 1 - r1+r1​≈1−r.

Use this approximation to write p0p_0p0​ as

p0=x011−GR−1=x011−(1+g)(1−r)=x011−(1+g−r−rg)≈x01r−g\begin{aligned} p_0 &= x_0 \frac{1}{1 - G R^{-1}} \\ &= x_0 \frac{1}{1 - (1+g) (1-r) } \\ &= x_0 \frac{1}{1 - (1+g - r - rg)} \\ & \approx x_0 \frac{1}{r -g } \end{aligned}p0​​=x0​1−GR−11​=x0​1−(1+g)(1−r)1​=x0​1−(1+g−r−rg)1​≈x0​r−g1​​
(37)

where the last step uses the approximation rg≈0r g \approx 0rg≈0.

The approximation

p0=x0r−gp_0 = \frac{x_0 }{r -g }p0​=r−gx0​​
(38)

is known as the Gordon formula for the present value or current price of an infinite payment stream x0Gtx_0 G^tx0​Gt when the nominal one-period interest rate is rrr and when r>gr > gr>g.

We can also extend the asset pricing formula so that it applies to finite leases.

Let the payment stream on the lease now be xtx_txt​ for t=1,2,…,Tt= 1,2, \dots,Tt=1,2,…,T, where again

xt=Gtx0x_t = G^t x_0xt​=Gtx0​
(39)

The present value of this lease is:

p0=x0+x1/R+⋯+xT/RT=x0(1+GR−1+⋯+GTR−T)=x0(1−GT+1R−(T+1))1−GR−1\begin{aligned} \begin{split}p_0&=x_0 + x_1/R + \dots +x_T/R^T \\ &= x_0(1+GR^{-1}+\dots +G^{T}R^{-T}) \\ &= \frac{x_0(1-G^{T+1}R^{-(T+1)})}{1-GR^{-1}} \end{split}\end{aligned}p0​​=x0​+x1​/R+⋯+xT​/RT=x0​(1+GR−1+⋯+GTR−T)=1−GR−1x0​(1−GT+1R−(T+1))​​​
(40)

Applying the Taylor series to R−(T+1)R^{-(T+1)}R−(T+1) about r=0r=0r=0 we get:

1(1+r)T+1=1−r(T+1)+12r2(T+1)(T+2)+⋯≈1−r(T+1)\frac{1}{(1+r)^{T+1}}= 1-r(T+1)+\frac{1}{2}r^2(T+1)(T+2)+\dots \approx 1-r(T+1)(1+r)T+11​=1−r(T+1)+21​r2(T+1)(T+2)+⋯≈1−r(T+1)
(41)

Similarly, applying the Taylor series to GT+1G^{T+1}GT+1 about g=0g=0g=0:

(1+g)T+1=1+(T+1)g+T(T+1)2!g2+(T−1)T(T+1)3!g3+⋯≈1+(T+1)g(1+g)^{T+1} = 1+(T+1)g+\frac{T(T+1)}{2!}g^2+\frac{(T-1)T(T+1)}{3!}g^3+\dots \approx 1+ (T+1)g(1+g)T+1=1+(T+1)g+2!T(T+1)​g2+3!(T−1)T(T+1)​g3+⋯≈1+(T+1)g
(42)

Thus, we get the following approximation:

p0=x0(1−(1+(T+1)g)(1−r(T+1)))1−(1−r)(1+g)p_0 =\frac{x_0(1-(1+(T+1)g)(1-r(T+1)))}{1-(1-r)(1+g) }p0​=1−(1−r)(1+g)x0​(1−(1+(T+1)g)(1−r(T+1)))​
(43)

Expanding:

p0=x0(1−1+(T+1)2rg+r(T+1)−g(T+1))1−1+r−g+rg=x0(T+1)((T+1)rg+r−g)r−g+rg=x0(T+1)(r−g)r−g+rg+x0rg(T+1)2r−g+rg≈x0(T+1)(r−g)r−g+x0rg(T+1)r−g=x0(T+1)+x0rg(T+1)r−g\begin{aligned} p_0 &=\frac{x_0(1-1+(T+1)^2 rg +r(T+1)-g(T+1))}{1-1+r-g+rg} \\&=\frac{x_0(T+1)((T+1)rg+r-g)}{r-g+rg} \\ &= \frac{x_0(T+1)(r-g)}{r-g + rg}+\frac{x_0rg(T+1)^2}{r-g+rg}\\ &\approx \frac{x_0(T+1)(r-g)}{r-g}+\frac{x_0rg(T+1)}{r-g}\\ &= x_0(T+1) + \frac{x_0rg(T+1)}{r-g} \end{aligned}p0​​=1−1+r−g+rgx0​(1−1+(T+1)2rg+r(T+1)−g(T+1))​=r−g+rgx0​(T+1)((T+1)rg+r−g)​=r−g+rgx0​(T+1)(r−g)​+r−g+rgx0​rg(T+1)2​≈r−gx0​(T+1)(r−g)​+r−gx0​rg(T+1)​=x0​(T+1)+r−gx0​rg(T+1)​​
(44)

We could have also approximated by removing the second term rgx0(T+1)rgx_0(T+1)rgx0​(T+1) when TTT is relatively small compared to 1/(rg)1/(rg)1/(rg) to get x0(T+1)x_0(T+1)x0​(T+1) as in the finite stream approximation.

We will plot the true finite stream present-value and the two approximations, under different values of TTT, and ggg and rrr in Python.

First we plot the true finite stream present-value after computing it below

# True present value of a finite lease
def finite_lease_pv_true(T, g, r, x_0):
    G = (1 + g)
    R = (1 + r)
    return (x_0 * (1 - G**(T + 1) * R**(-T - 1))) / (1 - G * R**(-1))
# First approximation for our finite lease

def finite_lease_pv_approx_1(T, g, r, x_0):
    p = x_0 * (T + 1) + x_0 * r * g * (T + 1) / (r - g)
    return p

# Second approximation for our finite lease
def finite_lease_pv_approx_2(T, g, r, x_0):
    return (x_0 * (T + 1))

# Infinite lease
def infinite_lease(g, r, x_0):
    G = (1 + g)
    R = (1 + r)
    return x_0 / (1 - G * R**(-1))

Now that we have defined our functions, we can plot some outcomes.

First we study the quality of our approximations

def plot_function(axes, x_vals, func, args):
    axes.plot(x_vals, func(*args), label=func.__name__)

T_max = 50

T = np.arange(0, T_max+1)
g = 0.02
r = 0.03
x_0 = 1

our_args = (T, g, r, x_0)
funcs = [finite_lease_pv_true,
        finite_lease_pv_approx_1,
        finite_lease_pv_approx_2]
        # the three functions we want to compare

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
for f in funcs:
    plot_function(ax, T, f, our_args)
ax.legend()
ax.set_xlabel('$T$ Periods Ahead')
ax.set_ylabel('Present Value, $p_0$')
plt.show()

Evidently our approximations perform well for small values of TTT.

However, holding ggg and r fixed, our approximations deteriorate as TTT increases.

Next we compare the infinite and finite duration lease present values over different lease lengths TTT.

# Convergence of infinite and finite
T_max = 1000
T = np.arange(0, T_max+1)
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
f_1 = finite_lease_pv_true(T, g, r, x_0)
f_2 = np.full(T_max+1, infinite_lease(g, r, x_0))
ax.plot(T, f_1, label='T-period lease PV')
ax.plot(T, f_2, '--', label='Infinite lease PV')
ax.set_xlabel('$T$ Periods Ahead')
ax.set_ylabel('Present Value, $p_0$')
ax.legend()
plt.show()

The graph above shows how as duration T→+∞T \rightarrow +\inftyT→+∞, the value of a lease of duration TTT approaches the value of a perpetual lease.

Now we consider two different views of what happens as rrr and ggg covary

# First view

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

This graph gives a big hint for why the condition r>gr > gr>g is necessary if a lease of length T=+∞T = +\inftyT=+∞ is to have finite value.

We can use a little calculus to study how the present value p0p_0p0​ of a lease varies with rrr and ggg.

We will use a library called SymPy.

SymPy enables us to do symbolic math calculations including computing derivatives of algebraic equations.

We will illustrate how it works by creating a symbolic expression that represents our present value formula for an infinite lease.

After that, we’ll use SymPy to compute derivatives

# Creates algebraic symbols that can be used in an algebraic expression
g, r, x0 = sym.symbols('g, r, x0')
G = (1 + g)
R = (1 + r)
p0 = x0 / (1 - G * R**(-1))
init_printing(use_latex='mathjax')
print('Our formula is:')
p0
print('dp0 / dg is:')
dp_dg = sym.diff(p0, g)
dp_dg
print('dp0 / dr is:')
dp_dr = sym.diff(p0, r)
dp_dr

We can see that for ∂p0∂r<0\frac{\partial p_0}{\partial r}<0∂r∂p0​​<0 as long as r>gr>gr>g, r>0r>0r>0 and g>0g>0g>0 and x0x_0x0​ is positive, so ∂p0∂r\frac{\partial p_0}{\partial r}∂r∂p0​​ will always be negative.

Similarly, ∂p0∂g>0\frac{\partial p_0}{\partial g}>0∂g∂p0​​>0 as long as r>gr>gr>g, r>0r>0r>0 and g>0g>0g>0 and x0x_0x0​ is positive, so ∂p0∂g\frac{\partial p_0}{\partial g}∂g∂p0​​ will always be positive.

7.6Back to the Keynesian multiplier¶

We will now go back to the case of the Keynesian multiplier and plot the time path of yty_tyt​, given that consumption is a constant fraction of national income, and investment is fixed.

# Function that calculates a path of y
def calculate_y(i, b, g, T, y_init):
    y = np.zeros(T+1)
    y[0] = i + b * y_init + g
    for t in range(1, T+1):
        y[t] = b * y[t-1] + i + g
    return y

# Initial values
i_0 = 0.3
g_0 = 0.3
# 2/3 of income goes towards consumption
b = 2/3
y_init = 0
T = 100

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.set_xlabel('$t$')
ax.set_ylabel('$y_t$')
ax.plot(np.arange(0, T+1), calculate_y(i_0, b, g_0, T, y_init))
# Output predicted by geometric series
ax.hlines(i_0 / (1 - b) + g_0 / (1 - b), xmin=-1, xmax=101, linestyles='--')
plt.show()

In this model, income grows over time, until it gradually converges to the infinite geometric series sum of income.

We now examine what will happen if we vary the so-called marginal propensity to consume, i.e., the fraction of income that is consumed

bs = (1/3, 2/3, 5/6, 0.9)

fig,ax = plt.subplots()
ax.set_ylabel('$y_t$')
ax.set_xlabel('$t$')
x = np.arange(0, T+1)
for b in bs:
    y = calculate_y(i_0, b, g_0, T, y_init)
    ax.plot(x, y, label=r'$b=$'+f"{b:.2f}")
ax.legend()
plt.show()

Increasing the marginal propensity to consume bbb increases the path of output over time.

Now we will compare the effects on output of increases in investment and government spending.

fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(6, 10))
fig.subplots_adjust(hspace=0.3)

x = np.arange(0, T+1)
values = [0.3, 0.4]

for i in values:
    y = calculate_y(i, b, g_0, T, y_init)
    ax1.plot(x, y, label=f"i={i}")
for g in values:
    y = calculate_y(i_0, b, g, T, y_init)
    ax2.plot(x, y, label=f"g={g}")

axes = ax1, ax2
param_labels = "Investment", "Government Spending"
for ax, param in zip(axes, param_labels):
    ax.set_title(f'An Increase in {param} on Output')
    ax.legend(loc ="lower right")
    ax.set_ylabel('$y_t$')
    ax.set_xlabel('$t$')
plt.show()

Notice here, whether government spending increases from 0.3 to 0.4 or investment increases from 0.3 to 0.4, the shifts in the graphs are identical.
